text: Morning mist clings to the windows like old gauze. The fire licks at the logs, and I stand behind the counter polishing a glass—on the third circle around the rim, I suddenly stop.
Not because I hear footsteps outside.
Because I suddenly feel certain—the door will be kicked open, and it will happen in the next second.
The next second, the door slams against the wall with a bang. Cold wind and the stench of alcohol rush in together.
A drunk stumbles in through the snow, like a ball of thorns wrapped in flame.
“Liquor! Give me—”
He doesn’t even finish before pushing toward me, shoulder slamming into the counter. The glasses rattle.
“Calm down, it’s too early—”
“Calm? I’ll show you calm!”
He grabs my collar, fist raised—I don’t even have time to block.
Then the door sounds again.
Not kicked. Not violent. A very light push—like someone turning the page to the next scene.
Alicia steps inside. Mist still clings to her cloak, silver hair damp and cold against her shoulder.
Her eyes are too bright—like someone who stared at a fire all night and suddenly started laughing.
“You didn’t take the second punch this time.”
“What are you talking about?”
The drunk turns and snarls. “Who the hell are you?”
Alicia doesn’t look at him. She looks at his fist—like it’s a pendulum that always drops on cue.
“You always arrive right on time.”
She tilts her head slightly, as if recalling an annoying joke, and her smile deepens.
“I was going to pretend I didn’t see this today.”
“But I’m not in a good mood.”
She steps forward. Not a charge. Not a threat. Just one step—like driving a nail into the floor.
“Let go.”
“Ha? You think—”
The sound of steel leaving its sheath is as brief as a laugh.
The drunk’s hand releases instantly. He looks stunned.
He glances down at himself, as if trying to understand what went wrong.
Alicia flicks the tip of her blade aside, as if brushing off something dirty.
The drunk staggers back toward the door, as if dragged by something unseen. A gust of wind swallows him, and he’s gone.
The tavern falls into a piercing silence. No one dares breathe.
I’m still recovering from my crumpled collar when Alicia has already sheathed her sword.
“You… you killed him?”
“Mm.”
She answers too lightly, like swatting a fly.
“Who are you?”
“Alicia.”
“No, I mean… why do you act like you know me?”
Alicia suddenly laughs. The sound is like glass touching ice—clear, dangerous, a little thrilled.
“I’ve been looking for you for a long time.”
“Long enough to memorize the rhythm of how you polish glasses.”
She taps the air twice, like keeping time.
“On the first beat you frown. On the second you pretend you’re fine.”
“Stop scaring me.”
“I’m not scaring you.”
“I’m… celebrating.”
Her breathing quickens slightly, like something barely contained is spilling over.
“One hundred and twenty-seven docks.”
“What?”
“…Never mind. You wouldn’t understand.”
She leans across the counter, close enough for me to see the bloodshot threads in her eyes—like a fire has burned there too long.
“Remember one thing.”
“I’m not here to stay at the inn.”
She pauses, and her smile twists into something wilder—like someone finally telling the truth.
“I’m here to keep you.”
My throat tightens. “Keep… me?”
“Yes.”
“I’ve tried many ways.”
A memory seems to strike her. She keeps smiling, but her eyes hollow for a second.
“Gentle ways. Normal ways. Human ways.”
“Too slow.”
She drops a set of keys onto the counter, quick—like she’s afraid I’ll change my mind.
“Give me a room.”
“How did you know—”
“Of course I know.”
Her tone is terrifyingly matter-of-fact—like asking why the sun rises.
“I know you keep the salt on the left.”
“I know you pause on the third stair.”
“I know you pretend to be calm when you see me—and your fingers shake.”
As she speaks, she watches my hands, like checking answers already written.
“You’re insane.”
“Mm.”
“But it’s not my fault.”
She turns and walks upstairs, her cloak sweeping the floor like a restless wind.
At the staircase, she pauses without looking back.
“This time, I’ll do better.”
She goes upstairs. Her steps are quick, light, practiced—like running a path she’s taken a hundred times.
I stand behind the counter, fingers still damp from the glass, yet the moisture feels like ice.
Every word she said feels wrong for a ‘first meeting’ morning.
And worse—I have a fleeting feeling she’s telling the truth.
When I look down, I realize she left more than keys. At the corner of the counter lies an old copper coin, its edge carved with tiny sigils, worn smooth by countless touches.
I pick it up. Heat flickers through my fingertips—like someone forced a ‘next chance’ into my hand.
【Item Acquired: LuckyCoin,20】 (D20 uses +1)
